Executive Summary

Introduction and Background
 The City of Boynton Beach Utility Department is committed to delivering quality drinking water and responsive service to its customers, and strives to be good a neighbor to the people who live near its treatment plants. This document is the Boynton Beach West Water Treatment Plant (WWTP) Risk Management Program/Process Safety Management Plan (RMP/PSMP), which details the prevention programs that have been implemented at the WWTP to prevent and minimize the emergency release of chlorine gas. 
 Because the WWTP stores chlorine gas above the threshold quantity, shown in Table ES-1, the City is required to develop a plan to prevent and minimize emergency releases of chlorine gas to the atmosphere in quantities that could potentially affect the public beyond the facility's boundaries. The RMP regulations are from the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990, which are detailed and codified in 40 CFR Part 68. The PSMP regulation is from the Occupational Safety and Health Act (OSHA) Standards, which are detailed in OSHA 29 CFR 1910.119.
 
Table ES-1 RMP/PSMP Threshold Quantity for Chlorine Gas
Chemical Name - Chlorine 
Location Used or Stored - Chlorine Building 
Chemical Abstract Service Number -7782-50-5
EPA RMP Threshold Quantity (pounds)- 2,500
OSHA PSMP Threshold Quantity (pounds)- 1,500
Maximum Quantity on Site (pounds)- 24,000

 The chlorination process at the WWTP is subject to the most stringent of the three RMP programs, Program 3, which has three major requirements. The first requirement is a Hazard Assessment, in which the effects of a release from a regulated substance could have on the public are determined. The Hazard Assessment for the WWTP has been completed and can be found in the document titled "Offsite Hazard Assessment for the City of Boynton Beach East Water Treatment Plant", located in the Control Room of the WWTP. The second requirement is a Prevention Program, whi

ch consists of 12 elements designed to improve the system safety and decrease the likelihood of a release. The third requirement is an Emergency Response Program, which requires development of a plan for dealing with a release in the unlikely event that one would occur. The second and third requirements are detailed in this document.
 Because the RMP and PSM regulations are very similar, the Prevention Program and the Emergency Response Program of the RMP also serve as the OSHA PSMP; therefore, this document is referred to as the RMP/PSMP. This RMP/PSMP is divided into 13 sections, each representing a paragraph of requirements from the OSHA PSM Standard.
 
Hazard Assessment
 A Hazard Assessment was performed for the Boynton Beach WWTP to determine the effects a chlorine gas release would have on the public. In this assessment, the distance a set endpoint concentration (3 mg/L) of chlorine gas would travel was estimated. In addition, an estimate of the population that could be affected by a release of chlorine gas was determined and sensitive receptors, such as hospitals, schools, and nursing homes, were identified. The Hazard Assessment considers two release scenarios-a "worst-case" and an "alternative case." As part of the June 21, 2004 RMP Update the Hazard Assessment has been updated using the 2000 Census data.
 In fulfillment of the newly revised regulations, the "worst-case" and "alternative case" scenarios are not being presented in the executive summary.
Prevention Program
 The Prevention Program, together with the Emergency Response Program, make up the core of the RMP/PSMP. The Prevention Program consists of 12 elements, listed below, which are designed to improve system safety and decrease the likelihood of a release. These elements were developed by the City of Boynton Beach with the assistance of CH2M HILL.
 
* Employee Participation
* Process Hazard Analysis
* Process Safety Information
* Operating Procedures
* Training
* Contractor Safety
* Pre-Startup

Review
* Mechanical Integrity
* Hot Works
* Management of Change
* Incident Investigation
* Emergency Response Program
* Compliance Audit
 
 The participation of the Boynton Beach WWTP staff in preparing the RMP/PSMP was critical to the program's successful implementation. Employee participation was valuable because it increases the safety awareness of the staff and it allows the staff's experience in operating and maintaining the processes to be incorporated into the plan.
 WWTP staff participated in the development of the Prevention Program through a series of meetings and workshops. They also participated in the development of the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA). The PHA was conducted on March 9th, 1999. The most recent PHA was conducted on June 4, 2004. A list of recommended improvements to the chlorination system was developed in the PHA meeting. 
Staff who operate and maintain the chlorine gas processes were trained in how to safely maintain and operate the chlorine gas processes. Initial training was held on April 20 and 22, 1999. The most recent refresher training was held on August 22, 2002. All other WWTP staff received initial RMP/PSMP awareness training on May 17 and 18, 1999, which detailed how the new requirements may impact their jobs. The most recent refresher RMP/PSMP awareness training was also held on August 22, 2002. 
 The remaining elements of the Prevention Program were developed with the assistance of the Chief Operator and the Maintenance Supervisor. These elements went into affect on June 21, 1999 and have been updated for the June 21, 2004 submittal.
 
Prevention Measures
 To protect the welfare of the community, staff, and the environment, the City has taken many proactive steps over the last decade to minimize potential hazards related to chlorine gas. It has satisfied and exceeded the requirements of RMP/PSMP, and has a number of preventative measures in place to guard against the release of chlorine gas. Safety features implemented at th

e WWTP include:
* Chlorine gas sensors to detect leaks and trigger safety systems.
* Emergency chlorine gas scrubbers that will automatically sense and neutralize any chlorine gas leak from the treatment system. The scrubbers are tested weekly to ensure proper operation and effectiveness.
* Automatic valves and vacuum technologies that will stop the flow of chlorine gas if there is a break in the piping system.
* Specially engineered buildings constructed to house the chlorine gas system and to contain a chlorine gas leak, minimizing potential impacts on surrounding areas. 
* Extensive training of all plant operators involved in the water treatment process on the use, hazards, handling, and safe operation of chlorine gas. Plant operators and maintenance personnel also have special emergency action training on how to respond to a chlorine gas leak. 
* Comprehensive planning and coordination with Palm Beach County's HAZMAT team in the unlikely event that a leak occurs.
